discussion.content:
Is correct BE
If you have NTP daemons on your server but you cannot configure them to synchronize time
with a time server, and you want to use Cluster Time Synchronization Service to provide
sy , y nchronization service in the cluster, you should deactivate and deinstall the NTP.

comments.content:
I was wrong, correct is B, C
If NTP is used, then the octssd daemon starts up in observer mode.
If NTP is not installed or is deactivated, CTSS is used and the octssd process is started in active mode.
Oracle Database 12c: Clusterware Administration 4 - 32

choices.A: Configure network time protocol (NTP) on all cluster nodes, and then start the Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) in active mode on all cluster nodes.
choices.D: If network time protocol (NT P) is not configured properly on all cluster nodes, then Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will start automatically in active mode when the clusterware is started.
choices.B: Configure network time protocol (NT P) on all cluster nodes; Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will then start automatically in observer mode when the clusterware is started.
choices.E: If network time protocol (NTP) time servers are unreachable on any cluster node, then Oracle CTSSD Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will start
choices.C: Deactivate network time protocol (NTP) on all cluster nodes; Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will then start automatically in active mode when the clusterware is started.

questions.question_text: Which two actions guarantee that time is synchronized properly on all nodes in a cluster after installing Oracle Grid Infrastructure 12c? (Choose two.)

choices.D: High Available IP (HAIP) addresses uses for the cluster interconnect
choices.E: Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) IP addresses
choices.A: Single Client Access Name (SCAN) virtual IP addresses (VIPs)

discussion.content: AE is correct answer. GNS IP address is static ip.

Correct is AB
Employing Grid Naming Service (GNS) assumes that there is a DHCP server running on the public network with enough addresses to assign to the VIPs and single-client access name (SCAN) VIPs. With GNS, only one static IP address is required for the cluster, the GNS virtual IP address. This address should be defined in the DNS domain. GNS sets up a multicast DNS (mDNS) server within the cluster, which resolves names in the cluster without static configuration of the DNS server for other node IP addresses.

Oracle Database 12c: Clusterware Administration 1 â€“ 16

choices.D: They require direct access to shared storage.
choices.C: They discover hub nodes automatically at startup.
choices.E: They may discover hub nodes without having the DNS delegation configured by network.
choices.F: Oracle database 12c RAC instances may not run on leaf nodes.
choices.A: They can be on a different subnet to the hub nodes.
choices.B: Grid Naming Service (GNS) must exist on one of the leaf nodes.

questions.question_text: Which two are characteristics of leaf nodes in an Oracle Clusterware 12c Flex Cluster? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I think option F is incorrect
Oracle RAC database instances running on Leaf Nodes are referred to as far Oracle ASM client instances. 

A is incorrect: All public network addresses for both Hub Nodes and Leaf Nodes, whether assigned manually or automatically, must be in the same subnet range. (same link)
D is incorrect
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/cwsol/understanding-oracle-flex-clusters.html#GUID-26BBAAB0-765B-40D2-B59C-642AE69A64DF

The correct answer: BCE
